problem: What is the slope of a line parallel to $2x+4y=-17$? Express your answer as a common fraction.
solution: We can rewrite the given equation as $y = -\frac{1}{2}x - \frac{17}4$.  Since all lines parallel to a given one have the same slope as the given line, our answer is $\boxed{-\frac{1}{2}}$.
chatgpt_solution:
To find the slope of any line, we can rewrite its equation in slope-intercept form ($y=mx+b$), where $m$ is the slope of the line. 

We start by solving the given equation $2x+4y=-17$ for $y$: \begin{align*}
2x+4y&=-17 \\
4y&=-2x-17 \\
y&=-\frac12x-\frac{17}4.
\end{align*} The slope of this line is $-\frac12$. 

Two lines are parallel if and only if they have the same slope, so the slope of any line parallel to $2x+4y=-17$ is $\boxed{-\frac12}$.
